awd_titl_txt: Algorithms, States, and Dynamics in Models of Disordered Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical and computational research aimed at improving our understanding of materials where atoms are randomly arranged. This class of materials, including magnetic materials, window glass, and superconducting materials with many impurities, can be strongly affected by their built-in randomness. The properties of disordered matter change extremely slowly over time. This slow evolution provides these materials with remarkable complexity and intricate memories, but makes direct simulation on a computer inefficient, as extremely long simulations are needed. The PI's group will search for novel procedures to speed up the simulation of such slowly evolving matter. These procedures will be used to explore the general properties of a wide class of disordered materials.

The PI's group will investigate the deep connections between computer algorithms and physics. As an example, algorithms that we use every day to find the shortest route on a map can be used to find the lowest-energy fracture path in a material. Algorithms developed in computer science to study complex networks (social, computer, or transportation, for example) have many applications to disordered matter. In return, physical insights about matter have suggested improvements in more widely applicable algorithms in computer science.

The broader impacts of this project include training of students in advanced computational methods that have applications in many scientific and technical domains. Computer codes developed for each project will be quickly made available for unrestricted use by other researchers. This project also aims to strengthen ties between theoretical condensed matter physics, mathematical physics and computer science.



TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Glassiness and complex energy landscapes are of wide importance in condensed matter and soft matter physics, as seen for structural glasses, random magnets, granular materials, and constructed mesoscopic systems such as vortex channels in type-II superconductors or artificial spin ice. This award supports work in condensed matter and statistical physics to improve both our understanding and our ability to simulate the behavior of inhomogeneous glassy materials. Numeric studies of models of spin glass alloys and other disordered materials will be used to explore general glassy behavior. Direct microscopic dynamic simulations of glassy models are often not possible due to the large range of time scales that need to be covered. Efficient algorithms and connections with computational complexity will be further developed to construct efficient optimization and configuration sampling methods for these challenging model systems. Scaling approaches and other analyses will guide the computational approaches. The goal will be to use simulations to identify the spatial changes that allow disordered materials to have complex memories of external parameter changes. More generally, this work aims to characterize and describe more precisely the high-dimensional landscapes that underlie such memory and glassiness. This characterization will include the investigation of the controllability of the low free energy states. For example, the effects of boundary conditions on the interior state of finite dimensional models will be studied through accelerated methods that replicate exhaustive enumeration with less cost.

Graduate students will be trained in design and development of computer codes to study complex physical systems. These new codes will rely on recently developed sophisticated algorithms and will include general optimization and sampling methods that have not traditionally been taught to physicists. This project will also focus on strengthening the interdisciplinary connections between condensed matter and statistical physics with algorithm development and benchmark problem sets for computer science. Such connections result from the related mathematical structures and large complex systems studied. Students will be trained in rigorous analysis and verification of the results of large complex simulations, including large data sets.

Codes developed for each project (e.g., exact sampling algorithms for two-dimensional random magnets, planar dimer models as might be used in quantum Monte Carlo simulations, and interfaces in random potentials) will be freely and widely distributed with documentation to facilitate both research by the community and advanced training.

por.por_cntn:
This project was located within the intersection of two of the major factors advancing the technology of our world: algorithms and materials. Advances in our understanding of physical matter and materials and in our understanding of sophisticated techniques in computer science have many connections, with discovery in each facilitated by the other. Examples exist across physical science of synergistic applications of advanced algorithms, including direct simulation of large numbers of atoms to machine learning for categorizing galaxies. Support of research in these areas leads to new materials, new algorithms, new theoretical perspective, and to training individuals for the work force who can connect computer science with applications to new materials and complex devices. Within this large interdisciplinary field, the goal of this project was to better understand “glassy” disordered materials using algorithms developed by computer scientists. Specifically, we studied applications of optimization algorithms, those that sort through many possibilities to find a solution that gives a maximum (or minimum) value of a metric, to understand the dynamics of these materials.

 

One example of optimization algorithms is for route finding in navigation apps. Often the goal is to minimize the driver’s travel time. The app selects a route using data for a complex network of roads and intersections. Out of an extremely large number of possibilities, the “best” route is selected. In materials, on the other hand, the atoms or electrons rearrange themselves to minimize some form of energy. This means that finding the arrangement for components of matter with minimal energy can be addressed with computer code implementing optimization algorithms, the class of algorithms that includes those used for finding routes on a map.

 

The contributors to this project used this connection extensively, adapting algorithms developed in computer science to answer questions about complex materials. The models for materials included impurities that make it difficult to predict the low energy state. These impurities also mean that the materials are “glassy”, that is, they take a very long time to relax to a low energy (optimal) state. The publications from two the project focus on two important features of glass models: the pace of recovery of a low energy state after disturbance and the uniqueness of the history of relaxation to a low energy state. These features are important in understanding how materials store information and evolve over time.

 

The two features were studied using the example of spin glasses, magnetic materials with strong randomness. Spin glasses are described by regions, domains, of low energy that are separated by domain walls. To study the recovery of a material to a disturbance, we took a low energy state, one large domain, and then randomly disturbed some fraction of the spins in the material, leading to multiple domains separated by walls. Over time, the domains expand, coalescing into one large domain. However, we found that the pace of recovery was surprisingly slow, even for a glassy material: The domains had to grow to a size much larger than the size of the disturbance for the model material to recover its initial state. To study the effect of environmental history on disordered materials, we studied the effects of different types “nurture”, the random forces exerted on the spins and the initial spins, on the growth of domains. We found that the possible domains seen were independent of the initial choice of spins. However, we found that the exact domains seen did depend on random forces. In summary, by examining dynamics using optimization algorithms, the project led to a better understanding of memory and slow dynamics in random materials.

 

During this project, two graduate students completed their PhD degree in physics, learning computer science algorithms and their applications to complex materials. In the last year of the project, the principal investigator was one of the organizers for a two-month long workshop on memory effects. Software was developed and shared, both publicly and with collaborators, to provide exact solutions for some model materials with disorder, with further release expected. This software supports further research in physics and provides a testing ground for other optimization algorithms.
